questions.question: Susie ……………………….. a new boyfriend.
questions.description: Either could be used here. However, the got form of have is more common.

questions.question: I ……………………….. fever last week.
questions.description: Got forms are not common with had.

questions.question: …………………………… good neighbors when you lived in the city?
questions.description: Got forms are not common with had.

questions.question: I ………………………….. a toothache.
questions.description: Progressive forms of have are not normally used with meanings that refer to a state.

questions.question: You ………………………….. to work on Sundays.
questions.description: In negative sentences we use do not have.

questions.question: Suddenly I ………………………. a thud.
questions.description: We use listen to to talk about paying attention to sounds that are going on.

questions.question: Can you help me ……………………….. my ring?
questions.description: The infinitive can be used with or without to after help.

questions.question: How ………………………. is she?
questions.description: We use tall for people, trees, buildings etc.

questions.question: You have got lovely ………………………… legs.
questions.description: Parts of the body can be long, not tall.

questions.question: How …………………………. Sundays!
questions.description: The verb comes after the subject in exclamations.

questions.question: How ……………………….. grown!
questions.description: The verb comes after the subject in exclamations.

questions.question: Stir well ………………………. I do.
questions.description: In comparisons we use as, like or the way. We don’t use how.
